newsitem.title: BELGIUM: First sigh of relief for Belgian Sabena.
newsitem.headline: First sigh of relief for Belgian Sabena.

text.p: Belgian airline Sabena SA, scrambling to recover from a disastrous 1996, said on Wednesday a drastic savings plan aimed at returning it to profitability was starting to pay off.
"We're beginning to book the first results of the Horizon 1998 (savings) plan," Sabena spokesman Erik Sclep told Reuters. "I think we're on the right track," he said.
Sabena, owned 49.5 percent by Swissair, had a 1995 group loss before provisions of 530 million Belgian francs ($15.6 million) and two billion franc ($58.8 million) net loss in the first half of 1996.

Chairman Valere Croes admitted last week that 1996 had been a bad year altogether, but the airline has declined to comment on media reports that the full-year loss was likely to be between four and six billion francs ($117.6 and 176.5 million).

"It's correct that the losses will be bigger than estimated," Sabena's Swissair-appointed chief executive officer Paul Reutlinger told De Morgen newspaper in an interview of which excerpts were published on Wednesday.
Sabena's structural problems were compounded early last year by a series of strikes which undermined passenger confidence and shaved its performance for key criteria, such as the seat occupancy rate.
Reutlinger said recently the carrier had six months to prove to Swissair that the negative trend was being reversed.
Sclep said passenger traffic in Europe was up 10 percent in January compared to the year-ago month and exceeded Sabena's own target by one percent.

Sabena also jumped to first place in the Association of European Airlines' (AEA) ranking of punctuality in December for the first time in its existence -- exceeding the Horizon plan goal which envisaged a top three ranking by 1998.
Sabena was still only Europe's fifth most punctual airline in November and 11th at the beginning of 1996.
"January also seems to be looking good (for punctuality)," Sclep said.
Sclep quoted Reutlinger as telling a meeting of the Belgian aviation club earlier on Wednesday he rated punctuality high as it proved that all divisions were cooperating well.
Sabena's seat occupancy rate was exceeding company targets for transcontinental flights and flights to Africa, he said.
The seat occupancy rate for Europe was in line with expectations but the link with Tokyo was still below par.
Sales on the Belgian market rose 19 percent in December, compared with the rest of the market which rose just six percent on average.
